The ''Les TrophÃ¨es du Libre'' contest is one of the biggest worldwide Open Source contest whose goal it is to promote innovative software projects and give these projects recognition and media coverage - recently also to motivate students and academic institutions with special prices. The competition is international, it is intended both to free development professionals and amateurs. The ''Les TrophÃ¨es du Libre'' contest is one of the biggest worldwide Open Source contest whose goal it is to promote innovative software projects and give these projects recognition and media coverage - recently also to motivate students and academic institutions with special prices. The competition is international, it is intended both to free development professionals and amateurs. Participating projects can capply for 6 categories: [[Security Information Systems|Security]], [[Video Games|Games]] and [[Multimedia]], [[Business Management]] and [[Education]].
â
The first edition [[2003]] had 113 applying projects from 18 different countries, [[2005]] 149 projects from 25 different countries. In 2005 the jury consisted of members from 12 nations and it was chaired by [[Mark Shuttleworth]], known for the foundation of [[Thawte]] and funding of [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], a [[Linux distribution]].
+
The first edition [[2003]] had 113 applying projects from 18 different countries, [[2005]] 149 projects from 25 different countries. In 2005 the jury consisted of members from 12 nations and it was chaired by [[Mark Shuttleworth]], known for the foundation of [[Thawte]] and funding of [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], a [[Linux distribution]].
